}} 'Hyperglycemia', or 'high blood sugar' (also spelled 'hyperglycaemia' or
'hyperglycÃ¦mia', not to be confused with hypoglycemia) is a condition in which
an excessive amount of glucose circulates in the blood plasma. This is generally
a glucose level higher than 11.1 mmol/l
(200 '[[Blood_sugar#Units|mg/dl]]'). Reference ranges for blood tests are
11.1 'mmol/l', but symptoms may not start to become noticeable until even higher
values such as 250â300 mg/dl or 15â20  mmol/l. A subject with a
consistent range between 100 and 126 (American Diabetes Association guidelines)
is considered hyperglycemic, while above 126 mg/dl or 7 mmol/l is generally held
to have diabetes. Chronic levels exceeding 7 mmol/l (125 mg/dl) can
produce organ damage.

The origin of the term is Greek: hyper-, meaning excessive; -glyc-, meaning
sweet; and -emia, meaning of the blood.
categories: Abnormal clinical and laboratory findings for blood
